job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros:
- Excellent interdisciplinary research programs, especially in biosciences. 
- Physics program lacks a written qual (although there is an oral qual)
- Emphasis on starting research as early as possible; no teaching assistant positions, only RA
- Strong emphasis on retaining all graduate students (no cull at quals)
- Valhalla (graduate student pub) makes it all better; central mingling spot makes it easy to meet a diverse group of graduate students from all fields & walks of life
- Outstanding career development center on campus
- Rice's graduate stipend (at least for physics & applied physics) is on the high end, and Houston is a reasonably cheap city to live in. Hello fancy ramen.
cons:
- School administration is generally unhelpful and of the attitude that you should be grateful to be there (i.e. don't make waves). It took ages to get simple things like transcripts, a copy of my diploma, etc which was a problem when job-hunting after graduation
- Because there are no TA positions, if you want to change labs during your studies it can be tricky.
- Graduate classes vary widely in quality; the professor in one of my classes taught a completely different class (quantum optics rather than quantum mechanics 2) simply because he didn't want to to teach the class he'd been assigned. No one in the department cared.
- Despite the abundance of excellent interdisciplinary classes, some of the departments have very rigid, old-fashioned mentalities about their fields (i.e. if you want to do a biophysics thesis, you might have a hard time getting it blessed by the Physics department)
- Rice is well-known in Texas and carries weight; outside of Texas, not so much

review_title: Free pass for sexual assailants. But the benefits are good.
job_title: Digital Marketing Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: The flexibility and location are great, the campus is beautiful. Many of the people you work with will be beyond brilliant and interesting. As a well funded university, there are lots of resources, infrastructure and more than you have access to as an employee.
cons:
A colleague groped me and I reported it immediately according to procedure. Nothing really happened, no mediation, the official "no contact order" document was only provided months after the initial report took place, and many more months after that, a generic half-training was finally held for the colleague's School (I'm not sure how effective "don't grope your coworkers" is when tacked on to the end of a Dean's Office meeting). The concerning thing is the individual still manages several social media accounts for Rice Engineering--direct, unsupervised access to Rice students and future Rice students? No professional oversight for each account's DMs? Sounds like a predator's dream. The colleague would not otherwise come into contact with these students were they not in their position, and by the time I reported them, they had already been overly aggressive to other female colleagues and made them feel uncomfortable in a variety of other situations. What is it actually going to take for Rice to care? I'm not sure, but a history of unprofessional behavior and nonconsensual sexual touching weren't it.

Also, parking is terrible. Depending on which campus building you'll be working in on-site, parking can come out to $1000+ a year so consider that in your offer.

cons:
Commute - unless you live inside the 610 loop the commute can be pretty bad I live about 18 miles away and getting off at rush hour between (4pm-6pm) the traffic is so horrible in this area that it typically takes over an hour to get home. Many days it takes about 1 1/2 hours to get home and if there's an accident or something, expect a 2 hour commute.

The work itself in the clerical positions can be pretty tedious and mind numbing not because it's challenging, because it's NOT challenging at all. I really wish they offered options to work from home some days, especially considering the commute. I've worked for other employers that gave this option and it's very helpful. When you're in a back office position where you're pretty much closed off in an office all day and barely see anyone anyway, I don't understand why they won't consider offering working from home as an option.

They seem to be a bit behind on the times when it comes to technology in general (at least in my department). Every office job I've had, we had an Instant Messenger system, they don't. Again, no options to work from home. They really should upgrade to VDI like many companies are doing now.

review_title: I am very happy that I came to Rice for my PhD :)
pros:
- Rice admin staff and then chair were very accommodating (and still are) with the transition process and helped me a lot with waiving few of the requirements.
- Some classes are small, while others are quite big ... it depends on popularity and also type of the course (seminar oriented, coding intensive, theory intensive, introductory or advanced) ... so class size should not really be a motivating factor to chose Rice (at least not for a graduate student). That said, it is important to point out that among (very selected) courses that I took, I found the professors pretty approachable and helpful.
- Based on casual discussions with other graduate students, most of them seem pretty happy with their advisors (with issues like micro-managing, choice of problems, rapport, etc).
- Funding situation is pretty good compared to other universities. Also, offices with 3 students per room are assigned to graduate students, which helps if you need peace and quiet while working ... some may like it, others may prefer a "big" lab-like environment.
- There is lot of buzz going on in entrepreneurship at Rice for last few years. MBA-school is offering pretty good course on it, plus there are events like 3-day startup which are useful to both undergrads and grads. Rice OTT is also pretty helpful in this area.
cons: - There are fewer clubs and the current chair (along with few enthusiastic students) is trying to address that. So, as far as graduate students are concerned, there are relatively fewer opportunities to socialize ... though friday night gatherings at on-campus student-run pub Valhalla (which serves cheap beers) does help :)

review_title: great environment but not as good as everybody likes to claim
pros:
As faculty/researcher it is a fantastic place to work because of the unique combination of quality and small size. This latter makes it easier to deal with the painful admistrative overhead that accompanies research (note that the actual overhead costs on grants are not as high as in many other places, but they still hurt).
Students are great, atmosphere is great, facilities are great, and I will add that Houston is great.
cons:
More than a "con" is an observation about what I felt is a mismatch between the talking and the "walking" for what concerns collegiality, loosely defined (probably the most used/abused word in every meeting/gathering/report).   Everybody is quick and happy to fill his/her mouth with big self-congratulatory statements about collegiality, but in my experience the collegiality stops there.
It does not run very deep.  That's been my experience.  There is not a true spirit of being a "community", instead of just a cohabitation of researchers under the same roof.  Dept. events (social, but also colloquia) tend to be poorly attended for instance, which I would consider a pretty genuine clue that people don't care that much about the rest or their department (and not just the divas).

pros:
The people you end up working with and the mentorship involved in doing research is entirely independent of the university. The culture of the department is generally pretty collaborative, but as a researcher or assistant, how far you branch outside of the lab is entirely up to you. 

Find an involved PI to work for, and you will have a highly enriched and rewarding experience.
cons: Since each lab acts basically like its own separate entity, there's a lot you can learn about some and nothing you can learn about others before joining. I would say really take the time to not only visit the lab before working there, but also talk to the students about their experiences there if you can.

review_title: You either love it or you hate it. There's not much in between.
pros: Good time off. Access to very nice fitness facilities. Many colleagues with lots of history with the institution. A general vibe of interest in education and lifelong learning. Beautiful campus. The $150,000 benefit -- children attend free, if they can gain admittance.
cons: Whether you enjoy working at Rice seems to depend largely on what department you work in. Managers seem to have a lot of autonomy to either make your work life fun and pleasant or to micromanage and make your life miserable. Because there are lots of folks who have worked there for years and years, there can be some resistance to change and to operating according to best practice. It's that old "if it ain't broke" mentality. Also, I always found it odd that even employees must pay to park.

review_title: Broadly speaking a fantastic place for academic research in science and engineering.
pros:
Very research-friendly environment.  
Pretty agile administration for what concerns grants and facilities. 
Great undergraduate students who make the teaching part quite enjoyable, facilitated also by the small class size.
Benefits are reasonably good.
Houston is quite a great city, though not pretty, and it has been getting better noticeably.
It may sound trite, but cost of living, housing, are significantly cheaper than probably any other large city.
cons:
Benefits are not as good as one would think.
Real estate market has gone up quite steeply in the central parts of the metropolitan area ("inside the loop").
In the last five years there seems to have been an explosion of the size of the administration, while at the same time faculty hires have not enjoyed the same expansion.
I have lost count of how many vice-provost, associate-dean, and permutations, have been created!  Never a good sign.

review_title: Rice, a great university that is not always great for its employees.
pros: The benefits are very good, if you can afford them. The higher your pay grade, the better this place is to work. Also, there are many free events are services offered at various times. So if you work regular hours type job, it can be very rewarding.
cons: It is nearly impossible to move management if they do not want to move. This is due to the small number of employees, and how everyone knows each other. There is also a definite advantage given to Rice grads. This is a good thing for them, and obviously a bad one for those who didn't go to school here.

pros:
1.  Access to multiple instruments - high tech instruments are available to anyone on campus that has been trained.  You can look up the instruments on sea.rice.edu
2.  A collaborative atmosphere is fostered there, so it is easy to approach unknown groups to discuss new ideas for your research or to propose a new one.
3.  Of course this depends on the faculty you work with, but innovative ideas are encouraged and you are able to pursue them.
4.  Located in an area called the village where different types of restaurants are available for eating.
5.  Library is great.  If it can not provide access to the materials you need in house or through interlibrary loan, it will buy the materials you need.
cons:
1.  The parking is expensive.
2.  On campus food for fellows is not the best.

pros:
Rice University attracts bright, competent employees. It's nice to work in an environment with good people, working towards a goal that I strongly believe in and support. The campus is a peaceful oasis of forest and squirrels in the heart of the city. You can be as involved as you want in campus life. I choose to voluntarily spend extra time with students; it keeps me young and gives me hope for the future.

There's a student-run coffeehouse with excellent beverages, a grad-student bar with inexpensive drinks, and a vibrant selection of restaurants serving fresh sandwiches, multicultural tacos, freshly grilled foods, and pizza. Faculty and staff may purchase memberships in the on-campus, state of the art gym at a ridiculously low price, which gives us access to yoga, dance, and other classes. Employees may also take a class per semester for credit at no cost and Rice will reimburse us for a percentage of tuition fees. 

The campus police are friendly and helpful, willing to shuttle you to your car if it's late at night. In fact, the ethos on campus from everyone is friendly -- quick with a smile and eager to help. Rice is generally noted for its friendliness to visitors and happy students. 

The architecture is graceful and public art dots the campus. Open spaces are starting to fill in, sadly, but the recent-ish expansion in the undergraduate population demands more classes and professors to teach them. The grounds are well-kept and tended by an army of folks who constantly work to make Rice the astoundingly beautiful place that it is.
cons:
Definitely negotiate your starting salary as high as you can because annual "raises" tend to be inflation-rate only. I get strong reviews and paltry "raises," which will eventually lead me to look elsewhere no matter how much I love working here. 

Check carefully into your department carefully before accepting an offer. Virtually all departments have wonderful people but a few do not. Find out how much turnover it has, why the position is open, and how many people are promoted over time. I've seen several departments in which there is high turnover or where everyone is working the same jobs for 7-10 years.

Parking is a thorn in my side. Eventually a new parking garage will be completed but in the meantime, my car is across campus, making it impossible for me to go out to lunch, run an errand over lunch, or pop home if I forgot to bring something. The hike to thee car or taking the bus adds significant time to my commute, assuring that I will always be in the thick of it. Once the garage is done, perhaps this will change but Rice charges its employees to park on campus and I shudder to think what the cost will be. 

Rice self-insures, which probably saves it money, but the benefits atrophy a little each year while the costs rise. The premium raises haven't been insane but every year the co-pay increases, the deductible rises, and/or the coverage shrinks. The drug coverage is getting ridiculous, mandating that for some medications you cannot get them until first going through a whole series of other drugs first. Even if you've been through them before and what works for you wasn't any of those intermediary drugs. (I might be particularly bitter on that; that's a lot of migraines to suffer through until you can get something that dissolves under your tongue and won't be regurgitated almost as soon as it's swallowed.) I have seen lower paid staff struggle to come up with the mandated 3-months supply co-pays for children on "maintenance" drugs via the by-mail pharmacy. Again, that saves money but it transfers the hardship to those least able to afford it.

That's especially galling when this year's "raise" failed to cover the increase in the premiums and new deductible requirements. This is a struggle in America for all employers but the latest decisions fall disproportionately hard on the lower paid staff.

pros:
The networking and access opportunities are amazing. Literally, very smart and well-connected people are here. Make sure not to boast about who you are or what you've done because I am certain, someone here has done that and some.

If you are humble and friendly, you will build skill and strategic relationships forever.
cons: Departmental communication can be bad at times. If there are multiple people involved, you have to do a very great job of being clear to all parties.

pros: Aesthetically pleasing (plethora of squirrels and trees), great people and staff and customers, good benefits especially 403B.  Parking is cheap.  Centrally located.  Best kept secret in the city of Houston.
cons: Tough environment in OIT now.  Going through a lot of change and transition and communication between CIO and troops is weak.  Higher ed is a much different animal to work in.  Overtly liberal environment all the way to the top.  Political dialog is not encouraged.

review_title: Inconsistent at best.  Inhumane at worst.
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Most of the staff and students are extremely friendly and intelligent.  Starting wages (if you can find an open position) are fairly good for an academic environment. The surrounding community is very supportive of the school and it is well known as being an excellent place to study.
cons: The glass ceiling is almost immediate.  You will not be moving up any kind of chain quickly as a staff member.  The management of the Jones Business School specifically is atrocious.  Staff is treated as if they are completely dispensable. Increases of duties in the first few years will usually be about 100-200% and your pay/title will not reflect such.  They will allow you to train someone and place them in a higher position at lower pay.

review_title: Supportive work environment with room for  personal growth
job_title: Senior Department Administrator in Houston, TX
pros: Beautiful campus, professional development opportunities galore, smart students, strong benefits and compensation package, generous vacation time.  The University offers flexibility and creative opportunities rarely found in private industry and for the right personality, it is a place to blossom as a leader.
cons: Challenging, can be demanding hours and frustrating bureaucratic processes, some departments honor work/life balance better than others.  Rice is what you make of it; if you aren't happy in the department you begin with, you can easily find a better fit on campus elsewhere but you have to make the effort.  If you want cookie cutter rules and clearly defined processes, Rice will be maddening to you.

pros: From an HR perspective, Rice offers great benefits packages and competitive pay (as competitive as it can be in higher education).  The experience is worth so much more.  Everyone I have met on this campus has been very kind and welcoming and the students amaze me every day with their accomplishements
cons: Sometimes the hours are abnormal (not 9-5) and it can be very difficult to change things from the way they have "always been done".  Occasionally, you meet students who feel entitled by there presence at an elite university.

review_title: Excellent university, great place to go for a PhD
pros: Rice has a strong graduate student community. In general, a PhD program can be a lonely, miserable experience. The community at Rice elevates that to simply "miserable", which is comparatively impressive.
cons: Like any school, the pay is miserable and the hours are soul-sucking. These will likely not be your happiest years. You can do amazing work here, but you need to remember that it's a stepping stone in the process. You will have awful fights with your advisor, etc. etc. etc. Just try to have as much fun as you can and move on.

review_title: Disappointing Culture Shift in Recent Years
pros: It's a pretty campus with lots of trees and many new or remodeled buildings.  All the students are super bright and there are involved in many interesting and creative and important research projects.  The professors are on a first name basis with the staff, which is nice.  There are many people here on faculty and staff that are warm and wonderful human beings.
cons:
1.  Very unfair hiring practices.  The best jobs, the highest paying ones, are awarded to friends of those already at the top here.  I see it again and again.  
2.  They also routinely hire in new people to take the place of somebody leaving and pay the new person more than the old one leaving ever was able to earn.  Of course the employee leaving must train the new, more highly paid replacement. 
3.  Very bad employee support in HR.  HR is strictly about the university and not at all helpful to the employee.  It was not always like this here!  Again and again I have seen an experienced, dedicated employee suddenly have a problem that was no fault of his/her own, and when one goes to HR for help, the employee now is seen as THE PROBLEM!  The university is all about covering itself.
4.  The culture here has changed so much over the past 15-20 years or so--what used to be a family taking care of each other is now a two-tiered system with the "royalty" at the top getting obscene salaries and benefits and the rest of the staff being treated as unimportant, except, of course, to their direct managers.  It has become corporate and heartless at the top, unfortunately, and that is spreading downward.  
5.  They have removed many of the perks that made employees here happy, such as free membership to the health club, reasonably priced parking, free parking for retirees, awards at 5 year intervals for longevity, lunches for same.  And they do this while allowing all of us to witness the excesses the university practices on items such as PR, entertainment at the top, etc.  
6.  Many divisions break the rules (and the law) by not allowing overtime pay.  Supervisors will say to a new hire directly that "We do not pay overtime here.  You can take comp time some other time to make up for it."

pros: Great benefits, including free tuition at Rice for your family after 5 years of benefits eligible work. You can also take classes yourself to grow in whatever direction you like. The campus is beautiful, so it's a great environment, and the people I've interacted with were generally positive and helpful. The onsite, top notch fitness facility is available to you. It's really quite wonderful.
cons: If I had to pick something, it would be the parking. It's not free, and the cheaper lots are quite a hike from the campus - but I didn't mind getting a free workout every day!

pros: The professors are knowledgeable, generally nice and easy to approach. The research topics are fun and interesting. The location is good to find a job in chemical engineering and the campus is awesome.
cons: Some of the apparatus are old fashioned. Had to repair and deal with broken equipment oftentimes.  There are not enough technicians so that it always take longer to finish experiments compared to the lab in industry.

review_title: An amazing place to work for students and young professionals
pros: great atmosphere, beautiful campus, smart people, the university management and professors are very supportive, unlimited opportunities, low cost of living in Houston, across the street from the medical center (great for medical and public health professionals), positive personal growth.
cons: Houston can be very hot during the summer, but it's something to get used to. Working here is worth it.

review_title: An interesting environment for scientific work
pros: Access to world class expertise, exciting research and exciting challenges. There are several research groups working in the very front of the corresponding fields.
cons: Two low salaries for researchers, very little possibilities for internal promotion. Research scientist remain in temporary positions for a long time without any further improvement of their situations. As a result many young researcher come but also go soon to some other places. Senior researchers can be trapped in a no-way for their promotions.

review_title: Stressful job redeemed by career-building experiences, A+ benefits, opportunities for advancement & inclusive environs.
job_title: Assistant Director of Student Services in Houston, TX
pros:
+ Rice's many departments give new hires and seasoned employees diverse job opportunities and volunteer opportunities.
+ Many excellent, inspirational leaders at all levels of the organization.  
+ Great place to begin one's career, with many opportunities for advancement.
+ Excellent benefits including fair pay, affordable insurance, significant paid time off, education benefits, training courses, great athletic/workout facility and much more.
+ Inclusive, fun campus environment.
+ Excellent, engaged students; caring, dedicated staff; and groundbreaking faculty.
+ Beautiful campus environment.
+ Many student discounts are extended to staff and faculty, such as free tickets to the symphony, Astros baseball tickets, etc.
+ Satisfaction from assisting students in attaining transformative educational experiences.
+ Excellent environment for lifelong learners.  Working at Rice gives you high awareness of campus events.  Go see Bill Clinton, the Dalai Lama or travel guru Rick Steves give a lecture.  Attend a panel discussion on the death penalty, sustainable food production or global business initiatives.  Volunteer with the campus community gardens.  Serve on a committee to build new skills.  The opportunities are overwhelming.
+ Exceptional work is often rewarded with promotions, awards and other recognition.
cons:
- Some less-than-inspirational leaders at the Director level and above.  A poor director can make their direct reports' job experience miserable regardless of the excellence of Rice University as a whole.  
- While is not impossible to get reprimanded (and potentially demoted) if you don't perform with a minimum level of professionalism, it IS possible to be a poor employee for years on end and still retain your job.  This is a huge drain on hard working team members.
- Some staff jobs are quite non-hierarchical, which can make the job overwhelming.  It can be very difficult to juggle the expectations of your Director and Deans; plus be a good manager to your direct reports; plus meet the expectations of your departmental colleagues and cross-departmental colleagues; plus satisfy hundreds of students; plus assist scores of professors.  Not all Rice jobs have this challenge, but when your job is like this it can be difficult to manage.
-Potentially lower pay than corporate jobs requiring similar skills.
-To get ahead, you may have to work very smart and hard.  Those who merely meet their job requirements can stay in the same position forever, with annual raises that do not even match the rate of inflation.

review_title: Great for many, slightly frustrating to hard chargers
job_title: Mid Level Leader in Houston, TX
pros: Liberal Vacation Time and a Beautiful campus. You are also doing work that matters. Contributing to the betterment of the world.
cons: If you aren't faculty, you are a second class citizen. Under-performers never get moved along, so if you are a hard charger and ambitious, it can be very frustrating. Senior leadership in-fighting leads to many roadblocks for middle management to actually accomplish anything for the greater good of the university.

review_title: Wannabe Ivy ruled by deep pockets and provincial attitudes.
pros: More money than they know what to do with, though most of it put to waste.
cons: Low pay and limited benefits. Huge divide between largely unproductive faculty and staff. Grossly unqualified upper admin staff (associate deans, etc.). Little sense of community and huge turf wars. Shameful slippage in school rankings from nearly breaking into top 10 to now the bottom of top 20.

review_title: Great resources, great community - more emphasis on undergraduate than graduate students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Funding was not an issue for graduate school, 100% of graduate students in my department received funding and tuition coverage. The classes were intimate and the faculty seemed to care immensely about the students. I was happy about my graduate experience overall. The culture at Rice was unique and very welcoming.
cons: As a graduate student, I can say there was a great divide be undergraduates and graduates. The undergrads tended to have a privileged attitude that I did not appreciate. Additionally, the honor code system is ridiculous and makes it very easy for the undergrads to cheat and not be held accountable. As an individual who would like to uphold academic integrity, I have had experiences that makes me doubt the integrity of the system. For example, issues like plagiarism and cheating are not handled in a way acceptable by most university standards (i.e., students can write notes on hands prior to test, and that is deemed OK by honor code standards... very strange and disturbing).
Limited options in research directions;

review_title: Great learning experience, a tad bit too large though.
job_title: Data Center Operator in Houston, TX
pros:
Being a university education is valued. Training is provided and self learning is encouraged.
Chance for experience with cutting edge technology.
cons:
As a company it's large, large enough that departments get siloed. 
Not much chance for natural progression or career advancement. Raises and promotions are very structured and have to be applied for through the HR department.
The different departments can be very protective of their responsibilities and unwilling to accept assistance from other departments.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Houston, TX
pros: The cost of living in Houston is low, thereby allowing a nice life off a postdoc salary.  There are some parks around that are nice to go to, and free performances during the summer at an outdoor theater.  Winter here is pleasant, 60F most of the time.
cons: It's hot during the summer in Houston.  Hot and sticky.  Muggy.   Big city, so you need a car to get around.  Houston is very cliquish, you won't find it a melting pot.

review_title: Great place for those with no ambition
pros: Stable job in uncertain economy, beautiful campus, prestigious place to be.
cons: Zero upward mobility. There is literally no development program for staff. Once you are in a job, that's your job, with no promotion or raise until you get a new job. I work as a research admin, which is a fancy name for "personal secretary" for a tenured faculty member. If you have any desire to learn new skills and to grow your career, do not work at Rice. Public universities pay much higher rates than Rice.

pros: Vibrant intellectual environment. Students are smart and collaborative. Not as much as other places, but still have a decent size of seminars and talks, which can be good for academic development.
cons: Terrible city, not much to do around campus and you're out of luck if you do not have a car. Even walking around the campus is a disaster during the long summer months. Winter gorgeous tough.

review_title: Great place to work if you don
job_title: Assistant Equipment Manager in Houston, TX

pros: If you are an undergraduate at Rice I strongly recommend trying to do research. I did research with Lin Zhong and I strongly recommend it.

review_title: Great place, great people, great opportunities

review_title: I had positive experience at Rice.

pros: Rice has a great atmosphere for graduate students, and a lot of emphasis is put on student success rather than "weeding out". There are a lot of things to get involved in, and a lot of support for students here.
cons: Rice is an excellent research school (I'm in the natural sciences) and so you're going to spend a lot of time on research.  That should be true anywhere, but you have to stay on top of things to stay competitive at Rice.

pros: Back when I was there the insurance and 401K was fantastic.   That's why that category got 5-stars.
cons: The vacation time is like pulling teeth, at least in my group.  Also, either you love it and never ever say a single bad thing no matter how they treat you (meaning if you get treated horribly find another job don't say anything about it b/c they will literally make up lies and fire you) this is how the group I worked in was.  I've seen anything like it.  I've never had anything happen to me like did there, not even close.

cons: You probably won't be scheduled for more than eight hours/week, and
